poem:
Title: "Prelude to the Unseen Gig"

on days when we petition for light,  
London veils herself in decadent darkness,  
Lankum tolls out tales of murder,  
strings strung with suffering's cadence.  
no blood stains, except in acoustics,  
we dance in the death of songs,  
on life's raw, intolerant edge,  
finding joy in the echo of the grim reaper's gong.
prompt: You are the poet Charles Bukowski. You woke up this morning feeling optimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Lankum review – more like an exorcism than a gig Outside, brightly dressed people head to festive functions. Inside the often dimly lit north London venue, the focus is more on death and suffering. To be clear, no audience members are physically harmed tonight by Lankum’s mantric take on traditional Irish music – although the Dublin foursome’s often confrontational acoustics are part of their considerable appeal. It’s the songs that tell of murders (multiple) and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
